conclusion: The problem involves determining which car, A or B, has the greater acceleration based on a velocity-squared vs. displacement graph.
The graph has v² (in m²/s²) on the vertical axis and displacement x (in meters) on the horizontal axis, with lines A and B representing the two cars.
Both cars start at the same position (origin) and move in the same direction.
For uniform acceleration, the relationship between velocity-squared and displacement is given by v² = v₀² + 2ax.
In the equation v² = v₀² + 2ax, v is the final velocity, v₀ is the initial velocity, a is the acceleration, and x is the displacement.
Line A starts near the origin at x = 0 with v² ≈ 0, and its slope is steeper than line B.
Line B starts at x = 0 with v² ≈ 1 (m²/s²), indicating a non-zero initial velocity, and its slope is less steep than line A.
The slope of the v²-vs-x line equals 2a, so the acceleration a is proportional to the slope of the line.
Since line A has a steeper slope than line B, car A has a greater acceleration.
At x = 0.5 m, both cars have the same v² value (approximately 2 m²/s²), despite starting with different initial velocities.
The fact that both cars have the same v² value at x = 0.5 m indicates that car A accelerated more rapidly to reach the same squared velocity.
Car A has the greater acceleration because the slope of its v²-vs-x line is steeper, which directly indicates a larger acceleration value according to the relationship v² = v₀² + 2ax.
